did.abstract: Reynolds Price (1933-2011) was a novelist, short story writer, poet, dramatist, essayist, translator, and James B. Duke Professor of English at Duke University, where he taught creative writing and literature beginning in 1958. He was an alumnus of Duke and of Oxford University, which he attended on a Rhodes Scholarship. He received fellowships from the Guggenheim Foundation and the National Endowment for the Arts, and his books were nominated for the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award. The collection is comprised of correspondence, writings, serials, clippings, speeches, interviews, legal and financial papers, photographs, audiovisual materials, and digital materials reflecting Price's career and personal life. Personal and professional correspondence document his education at Duke University, especially his studies under William Blackburn; his period abroad as a Rhodes Scholar at Merton College, Oxford; and his literary work and interaction with other authors, including Stephen Spender, Eudora Welty, and Allan Gurganus. Writings include manuscripts, typescripts, proofs, outlines, and notes produced in the creation and publication of all his major works, including: A Long and Happy Life; Kate Vaiden; A Palpable God; Clear Pictures; A Whole New Life; The Collected Stories; The Collected Poems; A Letter to a Godchild; Ardent Spirits; The Good Priest's Son, and many other books, individual stories, poems, and essays.
did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The (1) Correspondence Series is divided into the Correspondence, chronological subseries and the Correspondence, alphabetical by name subseries. The chronological correspondence subseries consists of letters to and from family, friends, teachers, and admirers of Price's work. The alphabetical correspondence subseries comprises correspondence between Price and other writers, literary figures, celebrities, and close friends including Eudora Welty and Stephen Spender. The (2) Writings Series contains various writings by Price and is divided into the Books, Scribner's Files, Uncollected Fiction and Nonfiction, Price Writing in Serials, Reviews by Price, Addresses and Speeches, and Audiovisual Recordings of Price Regarding Writing subseries. The Books subseries is composed chiefly of drafts, typescripts, and proofs of Price's novels, plays, autobiographical works, and volumes of poetry.

The (3) Events Series contains materials documenting Price's achievements, his education, and performances of his dramatic work and his speaking engagements, as well as performances, and presentations of interest to Price. The (4) Personal Papers Series has expanded significantly following the author's death. The Series contains many of the books, letters, art and photographs kept in his home, including personal health and financial records. The Series also includes personal scrapbooks, his postcard collection, and a collection of family home movies. Price's teaching career in the Duke University English Department is documented by the (5) Duke University Series. And manuscripts sent to Price by fellow authors and students make up the (6) Writings by Others Series.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Materials related to the life and career of Reynolds Price appear in several other collections housed at the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library. The Clear Pictures Film Footage Collection houses materials created and used by Charles Guggenheim in making his 1994 documentary film about Price's life (based on Price's own 1989 memoir of the same title). The collection includes many materials that do not appear in the published version of the film: research, film footage of interviews of and about Price, and electronic files. Documentation of Price's professional writing career appears in the records of the Harriet Wasserman Literary Agency Records. Materials there include correspondence, drafts and published versions of his works, and publishing contracts both with this agency and with Russell and Volkening, Wasserman's employer prior to forming her own agency. Extensive documentation of Price's publishing history can be found in the Jody Jones Hunter Collection of Works by Reynolds Price. In addition to copies of Price's books with major commercial publishers, the Hunter collection also contains many small press publications, limited editions, periodicals, and audiovisual materials. Finally, the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library contains copies of many publications similar to those in the Hunter collection. These items, cataloged separately from the Reynolds Price Papers, are searchable by individual title in the Duke University Libraries online catalog.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Reynolds Price Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift between 1986-2017.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arrangement follows creator's chronological dates, where available. Archivist added versions where dates were unavailalbe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Correspondence Series is divided into the Correspondence, chronological subseries and the Correspondence, alphabetical by name subseries. Materials arrived in different accessions and original divisions have been retained. The subseries includes multiple runs of general correspondence arranged in a loose chronological order. The chronological correspondence consists of letters to and from family, friends, teachers, and admirers of his work. Early letters vividly depict his relationships with family members and friends. Many of the letters dated between 1954 and 1958 concern his education at Duke University and as a Rhodes Scholar at Merton College, Oxford University. His early development as an author is documented here as well as in the Writings Series. From 1961 onward, letters also provide information about his career as a professor at Duke University. The alphabetical correspondence subseries comprises correspondence between Price and other writers, literary figures, celebrities, and close friends. These letters concern both personal and literary matters. Frequently the correspondents commented on each other's recent publications or on work in progress. Numerous letters to and from Eudora Welty and Stephen Spender reveal much about their strong influence on Price's development as a writer. The series also contains a great many letters from Allan Gurganus; Polly Holliday; Jeff Humphries; Josephine Humphreys; Wallace Kaufman; Joe Porter; Lee Smith; and William Blackburn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The (2) Writings Series contains various writings by Price and is divided into the Books, Scribner's Files, Uncollected Fiction and Nonfiction, Price Writing in Serials, Reviews by Price, Addresses and Speeches, and Audiovisual Recordings of Price Regarding Writing subseries. The Books subseries is composed chiefly of drafts, typescripts, and proofs of Price's novels, plays, autobiographical works, and volumes of poetry, many with Price's notations and revisions, and provides a thorough representation of the development of each. Following his death, DUL received the materials for the books Letter to a Godchild; Ardent Spirits; and, Midstream, which were added to their own sub-subseries. Scribner, Price's longtime publisher, provided the materials in Scribner's Files, offering insight into the publishing process. Materials include correspondence, proposals, editing and production notes, marketing and promotion information, and reviews. The Price Writing in Serials subseries contains published essays, poems, and short stories. The Reviews by Price subseries includes Price's writing about other artists' work. Transcripts of his speeches and interviews appear in the Speeches and Addresses subseries. And the Audiovisual Recordings of Price Regarding Writing subseries includes recordings of Price discussing, reading, or performing his written materials and is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The majority of Price's published books and plays (minus some small press publications and limited editions) appear in order of publication date. For each book, materials are then arranged in order of their writing and editing history. In cases of approximate or inferred dates, strict chronological order is occasionally ignored, with the main sequence of writing and editing the text--as reflected in notes, manuscripts, typescripts, and proofs--being favored over such later matters in the publication process as jacket copy, ads, and adaptations into other genres and media (such as screenplays and audiobooks).

did.unittitle: Uncollected fiction and nonfiction: articles, essays, journals, poems, reviews, and short stories

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in this subseries include drafts, proofs, typescripts and fragments of uncollected poetry, fiction, and nonfiction. Some nonfiction materials in this subseries appear to have been gathered by Price and assigned this title in the early 1970s during preparation for his first nonfiction collection, Things Themselves, as some notes and outlines recorded here reflect the final structure of that book. The subseries also contains a mix of titles later collected in A Common Room; uncollected titles that appear in their own named folders elsewhere in the Reynolds Price Papers; and other manuscripts that are unique to this subseries. Further materials reflect drafts and typescripts of uncollected works which are unpublished, or published in short format. Price's early student work from high school through his years at Oxford is included here. The materials are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Personal Papers Series is comprised of personal and family belongings; personal financial and medical documents; books from Price's personal library; family home movies; and, correspondence which was kept in a locked box in Price's home. This Series also includes audiovisual material of interviews with, and documentaries about Price; and, family, personal, and business photographs. Each subseries is arranged alphabetically, or chronologically, where this information is identified.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: RESTRICTED: Access to, and duplication by any means, of most materials in the Reynolds Price papers requires written permission from his literary executor. Prior consultation with the Associate Curator of Collections is required before permission can be granted. Please contact Research Services.
